title: How did one city, Rome, manage to conquer such a vast empire and hold it together for centuries? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ll throw my hat in. Rome’s semi-mythological roots were militaristic (see the Rape of the Sabines), which helped fuel a culture of citizens who were replaceable. One thing the Romans did well was winning an epic war. Probably lost on a casual student, the ancient Romans lost many a battle. They were quite persistent, and continued on. They had no navy but during their wars against Carthage (a Phoenician city-state with centuries of naval experience) they literally reverse-engineered their ships and took their land-based strategies to the sea. Early Roman sea battles were quite like land battles. At some point in time, many many centuries after their mythological founding date, they held a large-ish territory, but nothing comparatively massive in civilization’s histories.At around the beginning of the first century, they were only as large as a dozen other empires in ancient history, buffered by the Atlantic Ocean, the Sahara desert, and uncivilized peoples to the north - compare this to the near east, central Asia, and China, which already had centuries of comparable empires rise and fall for thousands of years. In this regard, Rome was simply the first major civilization in the far reaches of the world which already had seen similar political empires. And they had far and away less culture, scientific discovery, literature, etc., than other entities like the Chinese, Hindu/Indians, Iranians/Persians, Egyptians, etc. At this point their government was still, in name, a Republic - the Roman Republic. In fact, the period between Republic and Empire was a severe, long drawn-out crisis which lasted at least a century, with multiple civil wars and many civil strifes. During this period, it is only chance that they were not destroyed or at least curtailed to a footnote in history. So, at this point I’m trying to say that after 700 years of their mythological founding of April 21, 753 BC, they were not a “special” empire by any means. But it is the two hundred years after where they shine. We only know about this seven hundred years because they later dominated and left a legacy that we know about; there were many other civilizations that probably had more culture and domination during that period that we simply don’t study now because, as the saying goes, history is always written by the winners. During the century-long crisis that I mentioned, they abandoned the very inefficient Republic which was a government of a few hundred very rich people into an efficient Empire where the military was ruled by (usually) a single person. And here is where I can answer your question as it compares to other civilizations. If you look at a world map, from the west coast of Spain to the east coast of China, most of civilization existed in Asia and had already developed and warred for thousands of years. Yes, thousands. At this point, the Great Pyramids of Egypt were two thousand years old. Rome appeared on the edge of the world, in an area where there wasn’t civilization like there was in the middle of China or India or Persia. The vast territories of Europe it gained were backwards forests. By no means do I say that these were massive areas of tribal spearman overrun by gun-wielding armored infantry; what I do mean is that, they were technologically inferior and once conquered they removed major external threats for hundreds of years. The same situation in India at that time would not have provided the equivalent security against the Chinese or Sassanids. It therefore gained the benefit of Pax Romana, the Roman Peace, where there was about two centuries of peace without fear of marauding, due to the fact that it became a comparatively modern state in a vacuum, with its only enemies thousands of miles away. The same state in Persia, India, etc., was surrounded on all sides by comparatively advanced civilizations. Sure, there were ebbs and flows in technology and power, but give it a few decades and your neighbors will catch up. In the Roman Empire, there were no such obstacles except in the east (the Sassanids were their historical arch-enemy throughout the Empire’s history, even though most students think of the Northern Germans / Barbarians as such - not so to the contemporary Roman). It’s hard to put this in perspective, but you may know of ancient cities that were surrounded in walls. Those walls existed to prevent marauding warriors from pillaging concentrations of peoples for their woman and food. Unrivaled at that time in history, thousands of square miles within the Roman Empire contained cities that were free from fear of external war. Just two hundred years ago, cities on the Italian Peninsula within a hundred miles of each other warred upon each other. During the first and second centuries AD, there were no external enemies for thousands of miles. Imagine how many resources it must take to build a massive wall for every five to ten thousand people that live in your civilization. Heck, for every five to ten thousand people in modern time, we just require a few doctors. So with this great boon the Romans did not need to devote costly resources to security. The Romans had been absorbing Greek culture for hundreds of years. There were already Greek cities that brought their advanced civilization to the Roman nobilities’ doorsteps well before Greece was conquered. Every noble Roman would have Greek pedagogues. This infusion of education gave Rome the technological prowess that militarism naturally lacks, providing the civilization the means to both conquer and organize. The Roman civilization essentially had a free “power up” by the grace of their neighboring forebearers, the Greeks. This educational prowess was essential for the organizational skills required to maintain a large political territory. For the glorious-sounding twelve hundred years that Rome existed, really only two or three centuries was it a global power. There are hundreds of Quora answers and hundreds of books about the decline and fall of the Roman Empire, so I’ll not go there. For its few hundred years of greatness, there were many factors that led it there. So, I postulate that: It was rooted in strong militaristic tradition, important for surviving during its fledgling years.After its early history, it absorbed modern civilization from a declining Greece, giving it a major jump. This married militarism and education, giving Romans technological prowess.Geography allowed Rome security from most of its borders. The unpopulated barbaric European north, the Atlantic Ocean to the west, and the Saharan desert to the south, allowed Rome to only worry about the east.Appearing late in the ancient civilization scene allowed Rome to dominate once conquering its declining Phoenician and Greek neighbors with no major threat from other less-developed European civilizations.While there are countless instances of gaining vast territories in history, most civilizations lose them quite quickly. Rome adapted by radically changing its government from Republic to Empire, allowing it to maintain its territorial expanse.Feedback welcome!

The Romans had excellent diplomats to make treaties, highly trained soldiers to conquer, and an efficient bureaucracy to administer the empire. They were master builders, laying out roads that boosted communications and made administration easy, and created buildings that have survived through the ages. Behind every success story there is also a good deal of Luck, and the Romans had plenty of that, at least until its decline.  Latte crafted in Trastevere, Rome. An artifact of modern Italian culture. As for the Italians, Mussolini attempted to convince the Italians they were cultural descendants of the ancient Romans. After the destruction of the empire in the West, the Italians became atomized in kingdoms of various sizes until the 19th century, so modern Italy is a relatively recent invention and one whose ties to the empire are really archaeological and not cultural. I don’t think the military tradition of the Roman legions survived the death of the empire, so wouldn’t expect today’s Italians to have the same values

In my opinion the citizenry believed in the greatness of the Roman state. Sufficient was their passion that the Senate was able to mobilize one-fifth of the male population of Rome to fight and die in the Second Punic War. That’s a Spartan level of dedication. Combined with administrative prowess and the cursus honorum meritocracy, the Roman were able to create an effective and long lasting empire.

It wasn’t. In actual fact, you’ve got it entirely the wrong way around. It was the empire that sustained Rome. But in any case; Rome conquered a few nearby cities, and then those cities+Rome conquered more, and so on. So Rome, on it’s own, only conquered central and southern Italy. After that point it was the resources of all the cities and regions under Rome’s dominion that did the work. By the establishment of the Empire Rome had become more than a city. In a meaningful sense the whole Empire was Rome, and Rome became less important to that empire as time went on. By the end of the Third century it wasn’t even the most important city in Italy, let alone in the Empire; it had lost that title to Carthage and Milan in the west, and Alexandria, Antioch and (upon it’s founding) Constantinople in the east.

Because it wasn't just "one city" that did that. It started out as a city state, but through conquest and diplomacy became something more fairly quickly. At that point it becomes more than "just one city" because it is leveraging the resources of many cities, both as allies and as subjects. Even by the Pyrrhic war it was a large and powerful nation, far more than a mere city.

Good question, others will offer more complete answers but three things come to mind. First off attitude. The Romans believed (with reason) that theirs was the best and rightful rulers of the known world. You were Roman or you weren't, and Roman was best. Secondly, organizational skills. They were excellent organizers of armies and building projects, unmatched until modern times. Third, engineering skills. The Greeks build beautiful buildings and inspired the Romans but they couldn't build an arch or a sewer. The inside of their beautiful temples were a forest of columns there to hold the roof up.Don't get me wrong, the Roman Empire was a brutal place, but only slightly less so than the rest of the world.

Rome conquered territory and then incorporated the conquered territory in their system. They built an empire, encouraged colonies, facilitated trade, built roads, used a common language, guaranteed peace, usually tolerated all religions, and eventually put all their provinces on an equal footing. Most of all, Romans were organized. Provincials could travel to Rome and be successful or rise to prominence in politics. Romans could travel to the provinces to live and work. Roman legions were the best armies for many centuries. The Roman Imperial Army took troops from all over the Empire, made their procedures and policies uniform, and inculcated their legions into Roman laws, ways and customs. Eventually, the city of Rome itself became less significant and the Roman Empire more important than any one city.

Don’t confuse Italians for being Romans, even if they are directly genetically linked. And remember there was a period of about 900 years between the fall of the Roman Empire in the 5th century and the Renaissance 14th century where a lot of the knowledge and tradition that made the Roman empire so strong was effectively lost, except for historical records which the general populous wouldn’t have had access to. It wasn’t just Italy that was part of the Roman empire either, all the lands surrounding the Mediterranean see and all the way to British Isles to Mesopotamia fell under the Roman Empire at one point. The French, Spanish, English, Syrians, etc don’t see themselves as Romans any more than Italians do, sure that’s were it started, and that’s where the majority of the Roman ruins are, but there’s Roman ruins all over the lands that Rome had conquered. Italians speak Italian, not Latin. Pasta hadn’t even been introduced to Italy until 600 years after Rome no longer existed. I’d agree that Italians do not have a military tradition. And Italy didn’t conquer under ancient Rome, but Romans conquered under Roman control. The city Rome was just a capital, it wasn’t the Roman Empire.

Every empire started from a city extending in a kingdom and further. It is not Rome only. Think to Chartago or Ninive. Italy is Italy, not Rome. In V century even Rome was using mainly barbatian as soldiers. Why Italians are not good soldiers? They had less resources and definitely less leaders, but soldiers were valiant as any other. During the WWI one single commander, Luigi Rizzo over with a little boat of 16 meters, sank in two different occasions two Austrian battleships . During WWII six commandos over three “maiali” (man guided torpedos) sank two british battleship, one petrol tank and damaged a destroyer in the same night at Alexandria. At El Alamein Italian paratroopers stopped british first offensive by using bottles of fuel to fire british tanks because they had no guns. Currently, the carabinieri (military police) are sought as trainers of all new polices in Iraq, Afganistan etc. because of their technical skills and humanity.

Brute force. A martial spirit. Slave labor. Perseverance even after losing battles. Constant expansion. Encouraging trade. Making conquered people citizens. Openness to foreigners who adopt Roman ways. Public works projects (water, roads, post-fire rebuilding). Luck. Dominance of the sea lanes. Persia being far away. Germany being rural. Disunited enemies.

Military organisation. Not just the way armies fought, but their engineers who built roads that enabled troops to move quickly (for the time) around the Empire. And there were several Chinese empires which were comparable. Except most historians are Eurocentric and tend to ignore them. But there were also empires in the Middle East which were just as big. Think the Persians.

Macedon would probably be the closest comparison to the rise of the Roman city state into an empire. The city of Muscovy also won the battle royal to rule the Russian empire, but this was a bit more complex than the roman situation. The most important development in Roman history in terms of their ability to form an empire was the Latin war, in which the Roman empire finally allowed other Italians the same basic political rights and representation as full Roman citizens (citizens of the city of rome still got a few special perks, but Italian families could now enter roman politics). This not only had the important effect of stabilizing the populist politics which had been causing problems for the city of rome, but also established the doctrine that anyone could become Roman if they were assimilated into the empire properly. This is in part why the empire had so much staying power compared to other city state hegemons throughout history.

A combination of superior organization, superb tactics, strong leadership and weak neighbors that they took advantage of to expand until they crashed into the Parthian Empire that withstood their best and brightest.
Because it believed in and relied on science. As a start, think about having a fully functioning million people city, Rome, in those days.
